remixed_from.author: pjotrx
remixed_from.title: Parametric Seej Penny Catapult (all parts in single stl)

description.text:
I am having a ton of fun modifying the Seej 2013 Catapult, I am going to put my mods here, so I might add more files as I come up with ideas. Thanks zheng3 for making all these cool ideas bounce around in my head!! See instructions section for details about what's here. also to help educate your friends and family, best I have found under 2 minute slightly amusing, simple & straight forward explanation of home 3D printing, (made by and for schools):
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YpHv19jdloI

File = seej_catapult_FULL-SET_arm-mp-f1.stl
Arm Version "MP-F1" - I wanted to be able to shoot with the disk payload upright and flat, so I added a ridge to hold the metal disk while it is in the flat position, also added a place for my fat fingers. I feel like I have more control now.
Printed in PLA - 0.2m Layer Height, 1.2wall, 12%fill File = seej_catapult_FULL-SET_arm-mp-f1.stl
This was inspired by pjotrx who put most of the parts in a single file (total genius), BUT I wanted to have the flags in there too, so this is what I consider the full set although there are not any bloxen here so the fullness is open for debate, AND (warning) this file includes my modified arm, so if you don't like my arm version "mp-f1" you might want to swap that part of the file back to the original.
This print is basically 140mm-x-140mm (5.5"-x-5.5") so it should fit most printers at 100% size, but if needed re-size it to fit your stage. now when a freind wants to start playing I just load this one file and print, 3 hours later and some hot glue and we're in business.
Printed in PLA - 0.2m Layer Height, 1.2wall, 12%fill File = seej-flag_mp_2sided.stl
Flag with my initials on it, unless MP means anything to you this might not be very interesting to you, but the idea of adding YOUR initials might be fun.
Printed in PLA - 0.2m Layer Height, 1.2wall, 12%fill File = seej_battle_flag_4sets.stl
Need Battle Flags? this file is 4 sets in one print (12 flags total)
This print is basically 140mm-x-124mm (5.5"-x-5")

title: MOBIUS Cage mount for FPV racer RCX, QMD

description.text:
Cages designed to hold and protect a Mobius camera, it's attached directly to the quadcopter frame from the same screws holding the top-plate.
Designed to be lightweight (around 8 grams) and protective for the Mobius lens.
Available in different angles and for different quad models. I added a lens cap that fit the cage lens hole! to don't get the lens dirty in the way to the flying field!!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Mendelmax 1.5+

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: FOR THE CAGE: I printed mine in PLA and it works, however from my point of view printed in PETG would be more elastic and stress resistant, use a generous Brim of 6/8mm all around, use a light support everywhere for better results. FOR THE CAP: I printed mine in TPU flex 25 and 45 shore and they both works fine! it's quite snug fit, so in case you print in not flexible material you can scale it up just a little.

I noticed it's quite common solution for fpv quads.

author: skandale

description.text:
I was on a cookie cutter printing spree for Christmas, so I decided to make a few custom designs.  I created this one for Jeep nuts.  I recommend using food safe filament and making sure that you clean up any little strings and stuff that could end up in the cookies.  If you chill the dough well beforehand and roll it about 1/4" thick this cuts nicely with no need for oil or other release agents.
Best results were printing with 100% fill and 2x nozzle width thickness on sides and bottom.

author: Ptitscarabe52

description.text:
Kit pour ajouter une double ventilation pour refroidir le récente extrusion .
le support est flexible et évite les vribations

People says that the best way to tend a shirt is in a hanger, in order to make it easier iron them. But I don't like clothes pull on the ground, so to resolve it here it is... Clothes Line Elevator.
Clothes Line Elevator has two different positions. With only print one you can put in these two heights, just change the corner where is inserted. To give more consistency, you can put two at the same time in both corners, but the second have to be print in mirror mode.
(Ok, you can put a pair of socks, but that is not a particularly elegant solution)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ES
La gente dice que es mejor tender las camisas en una percha para que sea más fácil plancharlas. Pero no me gusta que la ropa rastree por el suelo, así que para solucionar este problema llega... Clothes Line Elevator.
Clothes Line Elevator tiene dos posiciones. Imprimiendo una sola pieza puede colocarse en ambas alturas sólo con cambiar la esquina en la que se inserta. Para darle más consistencia pueden colocarse dos a la vez una en cada esquina, pero habría que imprimir una de las piezas en modo espejo.
(Vale, puedes poner un par de calcetines, pero no es una solución especialmente elegante)

title: NO SUPPORT needed - Roal The Bratty Dragon Prototype

description.text:
I love this model, it's nicely detailed and very well made. The original illustration by Splotchyink has a great blue dragon with a pink tummy,I wanted to re-create that in print, so he is sliced and printed then re-assembled. He is printed with Faberdashery PLA - Electric Blue and
CHERRY BLOSSOM PINK.

print each section and assemble.
This was also a test of hollow printing, one side was printed hollow (0% infill) and the other side was 5% Tummy was printed with 10% infill
He is 2 x the original size to show off all that great detail, you may want to scale him back down if you have a smaller print area.
You don't need to use any support to print this model. :)

comments.text: Little question, how do you put it on skeinforge where it doesn't intersperse the entire model with fifty solid layers?  Because it seems that skeinforge likes doing that to me. with models of this particular type.
comments.author: SplotchyInk

comments.text: With organic objects you need to uncheck 'infill in direction of bridge' in Skeinforge this will stop it trying to 'support' over and under-hangs by adding the partial solid layers you can see.

This is my final design of indoor micro FPV quadcopter. It's based on my previous designs, but with some new features:
  • fits 3.5" propellers, which seem to be the best for indoor quad with 1306 3100kv motors
  • reinforced arms and base
  • LED plates between arms in front and rear part (30x7 mm, e.g Diatone led for ZMR250 will fit this space)
  • thicker spacers
    • Froggy 150 is a micro 150 size FPV indoor/outdoor racing quad which is easy to print & build and very funny to fly due to its size and agileness. You can squeeze it through every hole :) It is designed to be one of the smallest and lightest frames that accommodate 3.5" propellers and standard size components like 1306 motors or CC3D atom flight controller board. Here is a sample video from one of my flights to show that it really flies very good: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_XaYZakmYcA. It's capable to carry HD camera for recording like Mobius/Foxeer Legend or even Gopro/SJCam. We also do some indoor racing: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qn6DaZgi6AA. When printed in ABS with 100% infill it's also rigid and will survive many crashes. Total frame weight is about 35 grams (ABS, 100% infill, M2 self-tapping screws), AUW with FPV gear and 3s lipo 500 mAh is about 200 grams. My recommended setup:
    motors: 4x 1306 3100kv (http://www.banggood.com/DYS-1306-3100KV-BX-Series-Brushless-Motor-For-Multicopter-CW-CCW-p-962149.html)
    ESCs: 4x DYS SN16A (or similar size and amps) (http://www.banggood.com/ZTW-Spider-Series-18A-OPTO-ESC-With-SimonK-Oneshot-Program-p-983660.html)
    flight controller: CC3D Atom (http://www.banggood.com/OpenPilot-CC3D-Atom-Mini-CC3D-FPV-Flight-Controller-CC3D-EVO-p-970762.html)
    propeller: 3545 bullnose (buy 5030 and cut it to 3.5") (http://www.banggood.com/2-Pairs-Gemfan-3545-3_5X4_5-Inch-ABS-Propeller-Prop-CWCCW-For-Multicopter-p-1001334.html)
    battery: 3S LiPo 500-900 mAh (http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__25505__ZIPPY_Compact_500mAh_3S_35C_Lipo_Pack.html)
    FPV camera: mini PZ0420 (or Eachine700tvl) (http://www.banggood.com/Eachine-700TVL-2_6mm-Lens-1-3-CMOS-110-Degree-FPV-Mini-Camera-p-991027.html)
    video TX: FT951 25mW (http://www.banggood.com/Eachine-ET25-5_8G-32CH-25mW-7-24V-Super-Light-Transmitter-p-991026.html, http://www.banggood.com/5_8G-Circular-Polarized-LHCP-Antenna-Short-SMA-RP-SMA-p-965219.html) This 3S setup has very high power to weight ratio and flies really well even with HD cam. Software:
    BLHeli14.1 firmware for ESCs + Damped Light mode + Oneshot125
    Cleanflight 1.10 Luxfloat controller PIDs:
    roll/pitch: 2, 0.040, 30
    yaw: 6, 0.040, 5
    looptime: 1600 There is also a bigger version for 4" propellers (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1003801) and 5" propellers (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1069161). Have fun!

title: Probe sensor top support - bQ Hephestos

description.text:
I made this top sensor support because none of the other ones I found and tried fitted well.
They would either had a gap between the support and the fan, or the hole would not align properly. So this one fix for me a several things:
  • Proper hole aligned with the fan.
  • Small insert that goes in the fan hole to hold it steady in place.
  • Hole for the screw head so the stock screw can be used no need for longer screw.
    • I'm using it with this fan blower support:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:636924 This is to be used with the 0D 16mm capacitative sensor (i.e.: LJC18A3-H-Z/BX).
    Let me know if this works for you and feel free to leave a photo of yours.
    Comments for improvements are welcome

This battery holder is designed to use the existing screw holes in the chassis to ensure a strong connection. The body does not fit over this but I am currently working on a mould for a body that will fit. the parts you will need to make this work are:
https://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=34650 https://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=31812 The battery inside the car will need to be replaced with a cable running through the existing hole. I have found that this had made the car faster as the battery's have a higher discharge rate, and the run time is also significantly longer.
You may need to put a bit of super glue or epoxy on the inside of the holes to ensure the thread bites. Please contact me if you wish to use this design for commercial purposes.

description.text:
The Lightsaber Creation Kit (LCK) is made up of 15 main pieces.
3 Pummels
3 Grips
3 Joiners
3 Barrels
3 Emitters A set in Red
B set in White
C set in Blue There are extra pieces, which include an extension for one of the Barrels, buttons and switch pieces for the Joiners, and fins for two of the grips. Using no more than one of each item, and no more than 5 and no fewer than 3 total pieces, there are over 350 combinations that can be made from this kit. I designed the whole thing to print out with supports. Additionally only the parts with buttons or switches need glue to add their pieces, the building of the sabers require no glue and can be built and unbuilt. Each piece has threads on each end (except for the Emitters and Hilts) and there is a coupler piece you print out to screw the pieces together in the order you would like. Update: 2/20/16: I uploaded Emitter A,B,C remix with threading to take the blade from my derelict saber found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1309830 I hope to model more parts and add them to this system. I plan to take the known lightsabers and see if I can cut and edit them to work with this. The example saber in the pictures is;
Pummel_B
Grip_B
Joiner_A
Barrel_A (without the extension)
Emitter_A This required two couplers, one is printed in ABS like the lightsaber parts, and one is printed in PLA. There is one picture showing the PLA coupler between two parts. I would love to hear comments or see pictures of the sabers you make. This is modeled after a set that RM made and sold in 2009 before they went out of business.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 Micron

Infill:

20%

Notes: Printed some in ABS, I printed some in PLA. The shrink or swell of the plastic makes a bit of a difference, but just a little patience and it goes together fine.

Emitters A and B don't need a coupler, but Emitter C does.
None of the Pummels need couplers.
I modeled these in Autodesk Fusion 360

description.text:
After suffering lot of hours of trying to calibrate my delta printer, I decided to calculate a more accurate method to approximate the diagonal correction, supposing calibrated z height, and this method involves the particular Horizontal Radius of your printer. INSTRUCTIONS (Very recommended to read the pdf attached). At first, set to 0 any correction on your X,Y or Z Diagonal rod and use your real diagonal rod length. You must use same diagonal rod value for each tower so the Excel can calculate particular corrections.
Then print the calibration piece on the CENTRE of the printing plate, like the one on the image.
You must avoid any thermal dilation on the printing, so, you must print with max cooling, the given resolution, not so slow, and not so fast, 40 mm/s for perimeters will be okay. Then you must measure the distance between faces on each tower direction and introduce them on the spreadsheet document on "Thing Files". The pre-set distance is 75 mm, if you scale the piece you must edit that parameter on the Excel document.

  • Instructions of the Excel document on the Excel document.

  • Explanation of the method on the PDF

  • It's a very good idea to remove the wall dilation of the measurement.

• On slic3r, use 90% (for example) perimeter extrusion, on advanced settings, so print becomes more accurate.

  • Use brim, may increase precision.

  • Do not remove the hexagon from the printing bed, measure it without removing.

1.1
  • Redesigned spreadsheet to recieve the raw measurement.
  • Redesigned the calibration hexagon to give it more rigidity and use thinner walls, so wall dilation is less important.

Printer:

DIY Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

Nope

Notes: Use just 2 perimeters, check the image from the slicing on top.
Some maths and... voilá!

comments.text: Thank you, bro.  Here's a tip: sometimes using many tools for adjusting geometry could be inappropriate, the error committed by your machine precision is always there, you just can move it to less harmful aspects of your printing and if you trick too much the software eventually you may find yourself with no control over the error because everything is so messy. Sometimes is better to use a robust compact method to fake two or three geometries on the software, like tower angle, radius and diagonal rod. Least squares of echer 3D is a very cool idea but it has no transparency about how it works. My method sacrifices very little shape accuracy seeking dimensional fix because you always have to make an interchange if you don't know perfectly all the errors on your machine, but I don't know what the echer method prioritizes and what it sacrifices.

comments.text: The problem of using an aluminium bed is the polarisation time, the variation of tension in the bed take a while to affect the signal detector of the board. If you want to have more solid calibration, try to use your real dimensions,  tweak them a little by yourself to get the planar horizontal translation and then apply my method. The thing of having calibrated pieces of a size but not calibrated for another size happens because of the non linearity of the delta kinematics, try as hard as possible to maintain real physical values of your printer on the software and use only this method.

comments.text:
Nice work!
In the spreadsheet, you have a long calculation for the estimated Dx, Dy and Dz. but based on the same math you provided in the pdf file, you could easily solve for D. Given that
Dh = sqrt(D0^2 - (R - L)^2) - h
and
D^2 = (R-L)^2 + (h + Dh)^2
where h = sqrt(D^2 - R^2)
If you expand the second term D^2 can be canceled out and then you could solve for D.

comments.text: Under 0.5% of error is very hard to detect the source of error. The routine for correction is mathematically correct, it tries to make the delta work with a fake diagonal rod value to correct that dimensional error. Instead, the error can be produced by wall dilation or other parameters with much more influence on errors as the tower distance. It's very common on that kind of errors to have a tower distance error, try to increase/decrease that tower distance ( that worked on my z tower, with te same symptom).

title: Simple 80mm fan grille
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a very simple fan grille that makes use of some advanced feature of Slic3r to use the infill pattern as a functional part of the print. The downloadable STL's won't be sufficient to replicate the print, but unfortunately there's no option in Slic3r to export the arrangement used as a project*. See the "how I designed this" section for more details. (*) Slic3r allows to export the whole plate as an AMF file, that will store the modifier and its options as metadata, so I have added to the collection the exported file. Thanks to Xoan for his help in the comments section, sometimes using Slic3r is not exactly intuitive.

The OpenSCAD file includes geometry to create two separate volumes. these can be exported as two STL's by prefixing each with an exclamation mark before rendering and exporting. To replicate the one I have printed you have to first import the "main" stl, then select it in Slic3r with the right button and select "Settings" from the context menu. This will open an advanced section from which you can load the "modifier" stl, and whith this selected you can then add the following modifications: top perimeters=0, bottom perimeters=0, infill pattern=honeycomb, infill %=12. The size of the infill pattern is a function of both infill density and extrusion width, so this value is very much dependent on your printer capabilities. Other infill patterns and densities also work well, this is really mostly an experiment and/or tutorial for applications of the modifier options.

comments.text: You can export de part along with the modifier by clicking in "Plater →Export plate as AMF".
comments.author: xoan

comments.text: Cool, I did not know that. Will that allow Slic3r to re-import it complete with modifier settings, though? Or just the superimposed meshes?
comments.author: xoan

comments.text: Yeah, Slic3r writes metadata in the AMF file (XML format) to store the modifier settings.
comments.author: Brandano

remixed_from.title: Bearing Spool Holder for Up! Mini pp3dp

description.text:
This is a reinforced version using a M4x30 screw in the center of the axle, so it should not be as prone to break as the original version. By not screwing it all the way in, you can adjust the angle of the axle towards the Mini-casing, so the spool is perfectly vertical.
I added a slot at the end of the axle and a little slotted locking-disc that prevents the spool from falling off the axle.
Printed and tested on my Mini, and it works very well. It was just a bit tricky to remove the support under the hook when printing the axle vertically, but with a good knive it's not that hard. 02.02.2014: Uploaded a version with a longer axle (74mm instead of 62mm that should work with 1kg spools. 18.06.2014: Uploaded another version that should work with the Up Plus printers. Check the comments for the details.
(UP_Plus_Spoolholder_Axle_Reinforced_74mm_Long.stl)
Printed the axle vertically at 0.2mm layer and 75% infill, the locking disc as well. The bearings were printed at complete fill, with minimal support (you need 2 of the bearings)

description.text: The is a replacement mower knob handle I created for my Black and Decker rechargeable mower. Mine fell off and I did not notice it until the next pass on the yard when Clunk!, I ran over it. I have been limping along with a standard nut that keeps coming loose and requires a wrench to tighten so this was one of my first priorities when I got the 3D printer and modelling software. Two pictures show it in use on the mower and side by side with the original. I printed it at .15 layer but could easily be .2. I used 15% infill, plate temp 87 (Glass) and extruder temp 220.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

No

Yes

Resolution:

.15-.2

Infill:

15%

Notes: Supports make the interior nut area cleaner. It will print without the supports but it is not as nice on the finished product. If you are unable to print supports without using raft, I would skip the supports. The visible portion will look nicer and the sloppy part caused by the lack of support will all be internal and unseen.

The original stl files for this (and all other ULA rockets) can be found on the web at the following URL: http://www.ulalaunch.com/3d.aspx This is a remix of the ULA Delta IV Heavy model. I stripped off the base, broke the model into three segments (for printing at larger sizes), and hollowed out the boosters (for faster printing and use of less material). When printing, make sure the bottom segment is printed upside down, with the nozzles pointing upward. The connector pegs fit rather tightly, so either lubricate them (I use petroleum jelly) or resize them down a fraction. "Insider" tip: You can use the hollowed-out side boosters as secret hiding compartments! :-D

Contrary to a lead screw, a drive belt system is reversible. That mean it's normal for the plate to fall when the motor aren't in service and locked. And you can't solve that by tensioning the belt.
We usualy use the endcode to automaticaly lower the plate at the end of the print. And add some soft material or coil springs as mecanical stop.

This tool makes bending jumper wires for a breadboard a cinch.  It includes wire spacing for 2 - 16 holes (0.2" to 1.6").  I recommend using 24 gauge solid core wire.  This tool works well with resistors and other components. It also includes a 0.3" IC pin straightener on the end.  
Note this is a remix of another design by zim I found on Thingiverse.  I really liked zim's design, but had to make some adjustments to get the 0.1" spacing right.

comments.text: FYI folks, that length of CAT5 ethernet cable that you have knocking about in the drawer contains a whole lot of nice colourful 20 gauge wire.... ;)

comments.text: What a great idea!
comments.author: jzakariasen

comments.text: As someone who has been using these breadboards for more than 40 years, I think this is a neat idea.  (I wish I'd had this gadget back in about 1975!)  However, in recent years, I've gone to using the "flexible" jumper wires available from SparkFun and Adafruit.  (If I have something like an RF module that doesn't have 0.1" spacing, or the "center contacts" for an Arduino ProMini, I'll cut a few of the flexible jumpers and solder them onto the contacts to use with a breadboard.)  That having been said, though, I think this tool can, as you point out, still come in handy for things like resistors.
comments.author: ArizonaClark

comments.text: Thank you for the nice comment! I certainly do use a lot of flexible jumper wires too, they are very convenient! However, with a lot of wires, it starts looking like this: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breadboard#/media/File:Breadboard_complex.jpg. To counter the chaos, I like to keep the jumpers pressed flush to the breadboard, especially for things I know I'm not going to be moving around like power and ground.

Printing:
I printed this in ABS on my heavily modded solidoodle 2 at 0.2mm layer height and 20% infill. Painting:
The head is sanded then hit with Krylon 18 CT gold paint, sanded again, then another coat of gold (don't worry about masking the eyes). Any detail lines are picked out with a scribe. The sections to be red are again lightly sanded, the gold areas masked, then airbrushed with a combination of Iwata com-art acrylic paints to achieve the color I wanted. Sanding again before another coat. Then masking removed and an x-acto knife used to scrape the paint from the eyes until down to the bare ABS. A thin brush is used to run a black around the eyes and into a few of the detail lines to give depth. The base is assembled after wiring (see below) then painted matt black. Electronics:
The electronics are two (2) 3mm white LEDs wired in parallel with the positive wired to a CR2032 Button Cell Battery holder and the ground wired to a 1P Dip switch, which is then wired to the ground of the holder:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00E0IXQPY
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B007QAJRQA Run the two LEDs and wiring up through the head before running the wires through the base. The base contains enough room to route the wires then solder to the switch and battery holder. The battery holder is glued in place and the switch is friction fit.

Printer Brand:

Solidoodle

Printer:

Solidoodle 2 - Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height

Infill:

20%

Notes: I used simply3d to slice the model

Blender, Sketchup then netfabb I pulled an STL from elsewhere (I don't recall) into Blender and used limited dissolve to simplify the vertices and remove some issues with the mesh. I exported as .dae format and read into sketchup. I fixed up small issues, hollowed out the head to allow for the wiring, and designed the eye tunnels for LED lighting. The base was designed from scratch in sketchup using the dimensions of the battery holder and switch I happened to have laying around. Both were exported as .stl and then repaired in the free version of netfabb.

description.text:
I loved the look of Amplivibe's spool holder, but I needed something that would accept R6ZZ bearings, since I had a bunch left over from my 3/8" Acme leadscrew.  So, I modified the OpenSCAD file that Amplivibe graciously provided, and made the screw holes larger.  
Untouched is the hole for the screw in the legs of the thing; I have plenty of metric screws lying around so I didn't bother messing with that.

You'll need four of each of the following:
  • R6ZZ bearings (3/8" inner diameter)
  • 3/8" cap screw, 1" long
  • 3/8" Fender washer
  • 3/8" nut
    • Assembly is very straightforward. It looks like an M3x30mm screw with an M3 nut would be used to secure the legs, but I have a feeling it'll hold just fine without it.

description.text: This thing is a library to allow you to create customized water towers. Boy! I love water, and I love water towers. This is a parametric library. There are 2 files you should download: one is the library itself, which should go into a folder called "libraries"; the other is an example of usage of the library (test), which I usually place into a folder such as "user_designs". If you saved those files accordingly and you have OpenSCAD installed, when you double click the file "water_tower_tests.scad", OpenSCAD will load that file and you'll be able to build some towers by passing parameters to the library. author: jgsyel

title: Wanhao Duplicator 4S Y-axis pillow blocks & supports

description.text:
Both the front and rear y-axis shafts on my 4S were wobbling quite a bit after just 3 weeks of use. Wobble was ~2mm at the center of the shaft but it started affecting the print quality. There are many pillow blocks here for Replicator clones, but none of them fit for 4S steel frame + it's not fun to drill that hard steel so I decided to try to utilize existing screw holes. These wont eliminate the wobble 100% (at least not for me as my shafts were already bent) but it will make it insignificant (again, at least in my case). For the front blocks you keep the original flanged bearings, but add additional non-flanged bearings to keep the shaft straight near the pulleys. Print one of each pillow blocks and 2 of rear supports. You probably need to rotate pillow blocks 180 degrees in your slicer around x or y axis. Printed these from PLA 0.2 layer height, 15% infill, 2 shells. No supports needed if any kind of cooling exists. Additionally needed:
-2pcs M3x15mm screws.
-4pcs 5x11x4mm bearings. These wont require much dismandling. How I installed them:
Front:
-Remove side plastic frames (6 screws on each side) then stock front pillow blocks (2 screws each on side).
-Wiggle the shaft out from up side by turning other end towards back of the printer.
-Remove stock blocks and plastic spacers. They wont be used anymore.
-Loosen one of the pulleys to help installing new blocks.
-Install stock flanged bearings as inner bearings for the new block.
-Install new (non flanged) 5x11x4mm bearings as outer bearings. Push them in enough as the shaft is not long enough if you leave them just at the edge.
-Intall shaft back in the same way you removed by positioning the end of which pulley you DID NOT loosen at the front first.
-Push new block to the shaft to that end of which pulley you DID NOT loosen.
-Push the second block to the shaft and wiggle the shaft in its place. Rear:
-Loosen left side Z-axis slide upper mounting and tilt it towards front much as it's able to move (just ~2cm) to help manouvering rear Y-shaft.
-Loosen left side stock pillow block. Then by some patience you should be able to remove it, plastic spacer and pulley from the shaft. Dismount the right side from the pillow block to help moving the shaft around. You need to bend the shaft a bit to remove all junk. You can of course disassemble the unit more but I was able to install new bearings on the shaft like this.
-Push 2 pieces of 5x11x4mm bearings to the shaft and reinstall the shaft with stock parts.
-Tilt the Z-axis slide back in it's place.
-Replace outer most Z-axis slide screws with M3x15 screw found in spare parts bag that came with the unit and install rear support blocks to these points (keep the stock slide supports of course).
-Slide the previously installed bearings in the supports. Remember to check X-axis alignment before tightening those pulleys and bed leveling before printing anything. NOTE: Front blocks were really tight fit for gantry to fit at the very end towards front. Check that yours is able to move far enough (towards front) and if needed, file the block corner a bit.

title: Exhaust Vent For Flashforge Dreamer to 4" dryer vent

description.text: While I had some problems getting this to print it turned out very functional. While printing ABS on the dreamer the fans turn on intermittently but I think that will be enough to remove most of the fumes.  I will be installing it through an exterior wall next week and will see how well it actually works.   You will need to purchase (6) M4-.70 x 30mm and (2) M4-.70 x 35mm screws(my Lowe's only had the 35mm so they stick out in the picture) I would also suggest buying extra M4-.70mm nuts or plan on spending time looking for the one that got away. outside screws go in as originally positioned but the inner 4 have the nuts on the outside of the printer due to space limitations.

Printer:

Flashforge Dreamer

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard

Infill:

20%

Notes: I used ABS. My part started curling up and I had to add white school glue to keep it down, so I suggest using a raft. When it is loaded into Flashprint it comes out small, I simply moved the decimal point to the right in the scale setting(10.16= 101.6). outside measurments are Z 3.63" X 7.98" ( ( I know it should be in metric)

Final result End result is that I no longer get headaches while printing ABS. It takes a while for the fans to start cycling on and off but I am not smelling hardly any fumes at all. After installing the dryer vent through my office wall I decided that I needed a shroud to cover up where I butchered the cheap paneling, it also helps seal out any drafts.

Why I designed this. While I have been designing for over 30 years I have only been 3D printing for 4 days, so there may be a better method for printing this. let me know if you have better results than I did. I am very sensitive to smells, the candle section in stores tears me up to the point I will turn around and go down a different isle when i see or smell them. the fumes from ABS was giving me headaches and even PLA was not much better. This adapter was designed using AutoCAD Inventor While the part fits okay the hole distance between the 2 inner fan screws at the top are a little far apart(due to it pulling up, i think, since the bottom ones fit great).

author: Show

title: Mostly Printed CNC Z-Axis Motor Mount

description.text:
This is a re-design of the Z-Axis Motor Mount for the Mostly Printed CNC. I did this because it was very difficult to mount the motor before because the mounting holes were so deep. Finding a driver that is that thin and that deep was nearly impossible. Now the screws can be easily accessed with my version. It also seems to be much sturdier as well.
Update: 1/19/2016
I have been informed by the original creator of the Mostly Printed CNC that my design had a flaw in that the hole for the screw should be offset by 6.25mm. I have fixed my drawing to include that offset and the two files with "1's" after them are the corrected version of this model. I have not tested this change as the original one seems to work fine for me and I do not plan to re-print it. If you decide to try this version please be sure to let me know how it works for you.

Printer:

Razorbot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

30% or higher

Number = 1

Small, lightweight vise handle to replace the big clunky thing that comes with Kurt mill vises. This handle is not meant for heavy usage, use the original for that :) The handle that comes with a Kurt style vise is a Big Clunky Heavy (BCH) thing that is not meant to be left on the vise after you have used it to adjust the jaws. I find it to be a pain to have to put the handle away after every use, then pick it up again from wherever I'm storing it, put it back on the vise to adjust (usually about a 2 second operation), then pull it off and put it away again. Enter the lightweight vise handle. It may not be able to stand up to heavy usage or high torque, but for those times when you don't really need the leverage of the BCH, this little guy is a lot handier. It can be left on the vise while operating the mill and most of the time offers enough leverage to get the job done. Of course if in the long run it turns out this handle isn't durable enough, I'll just use the mill to make one out of aluminum or steel :) My first printed handle is extra-stubby, because I printed it on a small printer (Printrbot Simple). I also accidentally left the infill set to 20%, but it seems to be holding up pretty well so far. Customizer notes:
  • All dimensions are in mm. Hex size defaults to 19.6 which is just a bit larger than 3/4"
  • You can have 0, 1 or 2 knobs and 0, 1 or 2 bearing recesses. They cannot be mixed, choose bearings or knobs. Bearing recesses are untested because I don't have any bearings on hand atm.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

We needed a customizable bookmark to make a unique, personalized gift for a friend. We could not find exactly what we wanted, so we designed our own and thought we would share the design in case anyone else had a similar need. This bookmark is 0.06" (1.5mm) thick and has a 1.33" (33.8mm) high x 1.18" (30mm) wide x 0.02" (0.5mm) deep recessed area where you can insert a picture, phrase, or anything else you would like to use to personalize it. And, it also includes a hole on one of the upper corners so you can attach a tassel, ribbon, or cord. A nice website we found that shows how to make a tassel is http://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Bookmark-Tassel. These are the instructions we followed to make the tassel shown in our pictures. To personalize, cut your insert to size (printing on thin card stock and covering with the same size transparency film or clear adhesive label works very well and protects the personalized image). Once the image is inserted, use a toothpick to apply glue around the recessed border area of the image. Then, insert the cover into the recess to complete the assembly. You can further customize the bookmark with a message by importing the STL file into Tinkercad or similar 3D modelling software and recessing text about 1 mm deep into the lower area of the bookmark.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.200mm layers

Infill:

100%

Notes: We used MakerGear PLA filament with a bed temp of 70C and extruder temp of 220C to get the results shown. We recommend printing in the orientation shown in the 3D STL model file without any supports. The print shown was printed with 0.200mm layers. However, printing with 0.100mm layers will result in a smoother bevel on the cover.

remixed_from.title: Voronoi Chambered Heart (with small, medium, and large versions!)

title: Voronoi Chambered Heart (Medium) with internal supports

description.text:
I added some supports between the top of the inside heart and the outside heart.
I also added a base, to make it more stable when standing. This allows the model to print without additional supports, since auto-generated supports would be pretty much impossible to remove from the inside. I added as little support as I could get away with, but it will still be difficult to remove it after printing, since it's hard to get to it. I used a combination of a longnosed pair of pliers, a sharp cutter, a scalpel, tweezers and a nail file ;-)
In short: Be creative when removing the supports. They are designed to be cut in the middle, and when doing so, they often snap off in the attached ends. But they do leave very small spots that needs to be removed (this is where I used the scalpel and nail file.)

description.text: This project is of a model of DNA and its bases. All pieces fit together with Adenine and Thymine (represented with the blocks that have and A and T respectively) only connecting to themselves and Guanine and Cytosine (represented with the blocks that have and G and C respectively) only connecting to themselves. The sugar and phosphate blocks (represented with the blocks that have S and P respectively) connect to the bases all though there is left and right version of both. Once a section of DNA is complete, it can be connected to another to make a complete strand of DNA.

Objectives: The objective of this project was to teach students how DNA is connected. This project also shows students how to connect long strands of DNA and in how you could create different combinations through this. Audiences: This model could be used by almost any grade, age, or skill level. It would fit perfectly in a Biology or Genetics class. Preparation: Students do not have to have any previous knowledge or resources to use this project. It is advised that the student is taught about what DNA is and its role in the human body before using this model but not required. Steps: The idea behind this project is to visual represent DNA and in how it forms. This is shown though the Nitrogenous bases Adenine and Thymine only being able to connect to each other, the bases Guanine and Cytosine only being able to connect to each other, and the ability for the Sugars and Phosphates to connect to any of the bases and other sugars. The letters on the building blocks represent: A = Adenine, T = Thymine, G = Guanine, C = Cytosine, S = Sugar, P = Phosphate. Results: At the end of this project, students should have learned the parts of DNA and how they connect together. They should also have learned how DNA connects its base pairs in different orders to create strands that create a sort of code for an organism. An assignment for this project could be to create a DNA strand for students to recreate and grading based on the accuracy of the student strand.

This 3d model is a board that can be used to teach people braille. All of the letters of the alphabet are on this board. The V2 version can be read by totally blind people due to guide lines on the outside. One dash is the first line, two dashes is the second line.

Objectives: This model should teach both blind and regular people how to read braille in a simple way. Audiences The intended audience is anyone who has a sense of touch. Both blind people and regular people can easily learn the braille alphabet through this model. Preparation: You need little to no experience to use this learning tool, only a 3d printer to print it! Steps: To read the braille, place your finger on the first set of dots. You should feel only one dot under your finger, representing the letter A. To go to the next letter by sliding your finger over to the next set of dots. Once you have gone through the first 13 letters, move down a row and restart the process again on the letter N. The guidelines on the outside can be used to find the starting position. One dash is the first line, two dashes is the second line. Results: Students should have printed a easy to use braille alphabet board. This board should teach them how to read all of the letters of the braille alphabet. A suggested grading assignment would be to have the student randomly touch one of the letters and have them tell you which letter that is.

title: Geeetech i3 X - X carriage set with circular fan duct

description.text:
An alternative X-carriage for Geeetech Prusa i3 X. Made for a smooth rod separation of 45mm (not the default 70mm). It was designed to have some minor advantages as compared to the stock Geeetech carriage set:
  • Easier removal of the extruder from the carriage: Unscrew two M4 screws from the bottom and pull the extruder forward through the gap (backplate.stl)
  • Cable gaps for hot-end cables and motor cables at the bottom of the back plate -> No loss of build volume in any direction
  • Back-mounted (M3 screw and nut) cable holders and pass-through-holes allowing to fixate cables at the back side (back-cable-holder.STL) - alternatively a cable tie can be used by means of a provided additional hole
  • Fan shroud for the existing 40mm fan to cool the hot-end a bit (fan-duct-1.stl)
  • 3 sets of frontal mounting holes made for M3 nuts (Separation: 24mm, 40mm and 78mm) - easy and convenient mounting
  • Circular fan duct for perfectly uniform cooling flow (fan_duct.stl) - The duct is designed to have a distance of 3mm from the print bed to not to rip off the 4 binder clips. However, the minimal distance from the heater block is 1mm. Two LED mounts are provided.
  • Less weight than solid acrylic
  • The heads of the screws and washers are hidden within the backplate
  • See also the corresponding backplate: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1485794
    • Limitations:
  • The provided belt fixation (belt_fixation.stl) can only be used with low profile SC8UU bushings/bearings (i.e. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1196801)
  • You'll potentially need shorter M4 and M3 screws. This was designed for 10mm M3 screws and 10mm and 16mm M4 screws.
  • The back cable holder may limit your maximum/minimum X distance (in my case reduced by -3mm)
  • There is not much room for the circular fan duct. Take care not to melt it by the heater block.
    • _Update 23.01.2016: Fixed Belt fixation: Belt was not fixed properly
    _Update 28.02.2016: Added version for GT2 timing belt with 1.38mm height (Attention: some GT2 belts have a height of 1.7mm or 1.54mm)
    _Update 18.10.2016: Widened support for backplate (backplate v1.1.STL) for larger nozzle diameters.

Notes: I provided versions with and without manually designed support. The circular fan duct (fan_duct.STL) does not need supports. It has internal supports and manual bridges (see cross section schematic). Please select proper orientation of the parts for printing.

Push some M3 nuts into the appropriate slots. To mount the fan for the circular fan duct you'll have to glue 4 M3 nuts into the hexagonal holes. You can insert 0.5mm to 1mm thick circular cardboard onto the circular fan (see photo) for heat isolation.
There is not much room for height adjustment of the circular fan duct. The distance to the print bed should be 3mm to not to rip off the binding clips during movement. This leaves 1mm distance from the duct to the naked heater block. If you do not use binding clips you can reduce the height further. I have flattened my clips with a caliper by 1mm.

comments.text: Thanks! You are correct. The Geeetech Extruder is mounted by a thick bottom metal plate. comments.text:
It is a single M3 screw and the hot-end shaft nut which fixate the plate to the extruder-assembly. Compare the upper bit.ly link (last picture) and http://bit.ly/20ilcgS . I've also uploaded a photo showing the plate from below (the 4th one). These two things fixate the assembly well.
If you mean the frontal screws: They only hold the circular fan and should not touch the extrude assembly. So in my case, the whole extruder is fixated by two M4 screws (see 4th photo) which I found to be sufficient so far.

comments.text: Thanks. Well, so far I did not experience any drawback but also no benefit with respect to the stability or print quality. The carriage did not bend or something. The benefits 'only' lie in the easy access to the hot-end assembly, better mounting options at the front and the cable management. The fan duct produces an weak but roundly/uniform air flow. 3D printable power track chain.  This was inspired after a recent visit to a school that had tons of big machines with giant power tracks for various wires and pneumatic systems.  I wondered if they could be 3D printed.  Here is the first round that can house wires inside a 10mm x  10mm space through the center of the track.
Print the parts and simply snap them together.  It works like a charm.  The multiple chain link stl files can also be printed to speed up assembly time but you must carefully check your print settings to ensure your flow rate is not too high.  They can easily be dislodged from one another with a little bit of bending back and forth.
Could probably used for tank tracks as well, but haven't tried that yet.

This is a pulley mount system, made for our channel linear slide system.  This design mounts on the edge of the channels, allowing the pulley to be housed above the channels.  The pulley wheel is encapsulated inside the mount, and the ends are covered with end caps.  The pulley rope threads through the holes.  The mounts are double-sided, allowing for both the extension and retraction of the sliders.
The small pulley bracket is an alternative that allows the back pulleys to mount inside the channel to reduce the length of the slide assembly to fit inside the 18in sizing cube.
The new endcap is an alternative that lessens the amount of material inline with the rope.

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Yes

Notes: The pulley wheels must print with supports. The pulley mounts need to print as a solid.

Objectives: This model allows for students to place their pencils and pens down for a moment as they prepare for their next literary piece. Audiences: The intended audience is any type of student. Preparation: This model requires little to no experience. You just need to know that the pencil or pen goes into the open end. Steps: Place pencil holder with closed end down on desk or writing surface. Next place your writing utensils into the open end. Remove and replace pencils and pens as needed. Handsome Jack from the Borderland games will always be my favorite villain of all time. I used the obj file I found elsewhere on the internet, to create this desk ornament. I am still in the process of developing a stand that has a name plate on it, but the original model wasn't what I thought. Also this is my first model I've uploaded to Thingiverse, so go easy on me for any mistakes I've made. If you make one please add a photo to the 'I've made one section' Thanks UPDATE: I've added a stand for the original Handsome Jack but the letters will not print. I also added a new 1.5 scale handsome jack with appropriately scaled stand that will however print the letters. UPDATE: CrimsonIndustry, made a sweet stand that looks very Borderlands'y. Go check it out here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1324806

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1 mm

Infill:

10

Notes: I used Cura and set the Supports to 'Everywhere' then used 35 degree angle. This seamed to support his chin although it did add some unnecessary supports to his hair. With these settings it took just over an hour to print and used 1.52 m of filament. But your mileage may very.

title: Ironing Board Rack (for t-frame ironing board)

description.text:
Our ironing board folds nice and neat where it would fit snug against the wall - except that with nothing to hold it, it tends to un-click one notch and flop around in the way. Our closet is very narrow with shelves about 20" across from the space the board is stored in. I needed something to keep this stored neatly, and also raised up off of the floor so the wheels for our all-purpose cart would have room. Moving either of these items tends to start an entangled battle where both have to be removed every time either one is needed. I designed this because in addition to learning DesignSpark Mechanical and 3d printing, it was time to stop the madness.
DesignSpark document file included as reference example

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.30

Infill:

20%

Notes: I wanted a quick prototype so I printed at .30 layer height in Cura. I would recommend at least 20% infill. Turn it up 90 degrees (installed position) for best printing results. Probably would get better results with support for the screw holes but it worked okay, no major drooping.

Installation guide Hold your ironing board up to the wall with the top bracket in place. Underline the bottom edge on the wall. Mine happened to fit best 9" from the wall, which centers it in a hide-away just inside the door. If you aren't mounting this to solid surface (i.e. wallboard, no stud backing) then use wallboard screw anchors. First mount the top bracket:
Install the top bracket using the top screw hole first. I kept the screw holes small for marking accuracy, but had to drill a little bigger to get the screw started. after the top screw is in, hang your board to check the position. Remove the board after the fit-test and use a level to straighten the bracket, then mark the bottom mounting hole. Fasten the bottom screw. Once the top bracket has been secured, mount the bottom support bracket:
Hang the iron again for another test fit and hold the bottom bracket in place centered to align with the top bracket position (screw holes should align). The bottom bracket should fit snug against the bottom (back?) ironing board stand brace. Mark the position with a pencil. Remove the board, and re-position the bottom brace to mark the screw holes. Use the same method in the previous step (fasten top screw, confirm position with fit check, level, and fasten bottom screw). be sure the iron is completely folded shut - you should be able to hold it against the wall just above the top rack and drop it into both holders, snug against the wall.

I noticed that the frame of the ironing board feet are t-shaped, not a "y" style arrangement as some are, and thought it may be easy to make a holder for it. This top and bottom rack arrangement keeps the board neatly folded, stored where it's not touching the floor, and flat against the wall.
I got my calipers out and noted that the diameter of my ironing board legs is about 30 mm. I did notice that the top (front when standing) legs have a Y brace in the middle that spreads out to about 60 mm, so I adjusted the center to make room for clearance. The same is true of the bottom end, but it's facing inward, so I narrowed the gap for compact and stable support.
My first top-bracket design proved too narrow in testing due to the internal y-brace. After some design changes, I copied the top bracket and edited it to make the bottom. This was printed in PLA and should stand up to normal use, but this will be updated if a re-design or heavier infill print is needed after live testing.
Note: there is a small flaw in one of the top braces, i.e. it's not perfectly symmetrical due to an edge-rounding one one corner that changed somehow. Due to learning-curve (no pun intended) and the minor difference, I may try to resolve this later. If you are new to designing, it may be best to prove-out your dimensions and usability, then take your time when applying finishing touches.

title: Glow in the Dark Nerf Gun Scope Reticle Sight

description.text:
I modded this existing scope by removing the sights and adding my own. i also corrected the dimensions of the rail mount to eliminate all the post processing that was required to get it to fit. Print it Vertically and it comes out great. I designed the reticle as a separate piece to be printed out of glow in the dark material and then glued in. Its profile fits the ID of the sight perfectly. Credit to Kitka for their scope I found here :
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:57413 This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/eP6b0IHhmnc

comments.text: Great Thingi, thanks for sharing. Just wanted to let you know that there is a gap between both objects resulting in that the scope is "floating" when compared to the crosshair. Regards.

author: MooseAMoose

description.text:
A small 1/4" retaining clip. 
A 1/4" rod fits perfectly through skate bearings. I used them to build my spool holder.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes: Printed in ABS.

This is an End stop holder that is easily configurable,
If either of the clamp flags are not needed, they can be broken off withough compromising the strength of the rest of the unit. I originally designed this for my Prusa i2, as (like most Prusa owners) i found about 13mm of My Y-axis movement had been strangled by the existing setup, this reclaimed me that extra bit of difference - since then it's come in useful for a number of printer designs... The spacings on the flag are correct for the majority of mechanical switches - but I can always modify this for anyone, if you ask nicely ;)\

Print fairly solid, with an extra shell (as with all clamps - this will be under stress)
I recommend at least 30% infill - preferably honeycomb, 2 shells / perimeters and a low layer height, Though this should function adequately with pretty much any old settings. attach your endstop switch, captivate a nut or two in the traps, place on your printer and tighten...
Voila!
